description: From Middle English ones, from Old English ānes, a remodelling (after ān (“one”)) of ǣnes, itself an extension of ǣne (“once”) with the genitival suffix -es. Compare Old Saxon ēnes (“once”), Old High German eines, einēst (“once”), modern German einst (“once”). More at one (including regarding the development of the pronunciation) and -s.

examples: I have only once eaten pizza.

entries.meaning: (temporal location) Formerly; during some period in the past.
examples: He was once the most handsome man around.
I once had a bicycle just like that one.
Wang notes that flowers have rooted and grow in the area once covered with ice.
The wisdom of God thought fit to acquaint David with that court which we shall once govern.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) Multiplied by one: indicating that a number is multiplied by one.
